metadata.sermon_start_end: We almost always preach about men. A great deal is lost, I think, when we overlook a full half of the human family. And so, now, I want to preach about some women. I wanted to call this "A Family Love Story," but that does not quite say [...] No matter whether male or female, I'd rather hear from him or her the riches of the pure and simple gospel than all of the astonishing insights of science. I'd rather have Jesus; I'd rather have Jesus than anything this world affords.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses the book of Ruth as a springboard for general themes of migration, suffering, and gender equality. It fails Dekker's requirement to find what is unique to THIS text. The preacher treats the text as a 'replica' of general human experience rather than a specific, non-reproducible Word of God.
quotes: When one looks back upon Naomi... one hears a replica of what many of us have gone through.
The word God is mentioned very little in this book, and yet it is one of the noble expositions on... theodicy.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the specific theological 'novum' of Ruth 1 that cannot be found in other migration stories or biblical narratives. Move away from treating the text as a 'replica' of common experience.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic narrative exposition of the Moabite context and the family history. However, it lacks the depth of Hebrew linguistic insight or rigorous theological exegesis required by Dekker. It remains at the level of storytelling.
quotes: They travel east of the Jordan to Moab, whose purple hills form at evening an almost somber background...
These lads, Mahlon and Chilion, marry Moabite girls, lovely in their lithe, highland beauty.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate deeper exegetical insights into the covenantal implications of a Moabite entering Israel, beyond mere 'lithe beauty' and 'purple hills'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is highly concrete regarding the Black American experience and the role of women in the church. It addresses the zeitgeist (racism, sexism) directly. However, Dekker warns against application becoming a 'speech' about refugees or social issues detached from the specific text.
quotes: Some competent person ought to set down in a skillful way the account of our black migrations in America...
As the nation has chosen to turn away from its democratic vision by its choice of racism and sexism...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the socio-political application is strictly derived from the text's specific logic rather than using the text as an illustrative parallel for a pre-existing social critique.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured in blocks: narrative retelling followed by long anecdotal or political sections (Southern University, Richmond Monitor, personal career). The 'present of revelation' where text and hearer converge is interrupted by lengthy historical digressions.
quotes: I spoke at Southern University and spent a day or two among the gentle people of my upbringing. I saw people there...
In 1854, the Richmond Monitor... printed an editorial...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Shorten the historical anecdotes and weave the contemporary application directly into the verse-by-verse exposition to maintain the 'one movement' Dekker describes.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery (grief, migration, oppression) and gratitude (the hymn, the 'wonderful day') are present. Redemption is linked to the 'covenant of grace.' However, the misery is often framed more sociologically than as 'misery before God.'
quotes: Life is rarely one thing or the other. It is almost always a mixture of joy and sorrow...
This Moabite girl... enters the covenant of grace.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by addressing the spiritual lostness or the theological weight of Naomi's 'emptiness' rather than just general 'sunshine and shadows'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The preacher mentions Orpah 'missing life' and the tragedy of turning away from the 'meaning of life.' This hints at the two ways, but it is framed more as a loss of 'direction and purpose' than a theological 'destruction' or 'life'.
quotes: How sad it is for anybody to miss life, but how doubly tragic it is for any person to come close to the meaning of life... and then turn away from it.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Sharpen the consequence of the 'two ways.' Define 'missing life' not just as a lack of purpose, but as the theological reality of being lost in time or eternity.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos in the sense that the sermon ends with a strong personal testimony and the lineage of David. However, the connection between the text of Ruth and the 'nail-pierced hand' feels somewhat appended rather than exegetically demanded.
quotes: ...and of that lineage comes the Savior of the world.
I'd rather have Jesus than silver or gold...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the telos of the specific text's logic (the kinsman-redeemer theme, perhaps) rather than switching to a general evangelical hymn at the end.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely falls just under the 20-minute threshold at a measured pace. According to Thesis 8, it risks lacking the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical middle section to ensure the sermon crosses the 20-minute mark with substantive biblical content rather than anecdotal filler.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekkerâ€™s ideal primarily because it treats the biblical text as a 'replica' or illustration for general human and social themes rather than a unique Word of God. While the application to the Black American experience and gender issues is concrete and sharp, it often overshadows the specific exposition of Ruth. The structure is blocky, separating historical anecdotes from the text, which hinders the 'interwoven' movement Dekker demands.
strengths: Concrete application regarding racism and sexism, avoiding the 'general truths' Dekker forbids.
Strong emphasis on the 'covenant of grace' as the ultimate destination (telos) of the narrative.
Serious treatment of human misery and the 'after a while' of suffering.
weaknesses: The specific 'novum' of the text (what is found nowhere else) is buried under general themes of migration.
Excessive anecdotal length (Richmond Monitor, Southern University) that functions as a speech rather than a sermon.
The sermon likely fails the 20-minute duration requirement for depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate speech with strong homiletical moments, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It relies too heavily on the preacher's biography and social history at the expense of the specific, current, proclamatory Word of the text itself.
